docs.title: Remote access failed
docs.text:
• Check the node access and resource access settings of the network topology map to confirm that the device is allowed to be accessed.

  • Check the firewall settings of the accessed device to ensure that the device is allowed to be accessed by the router.

  • Try to restart (stop and then start) the astrowarp network.

  • Try to switch the server node.

docs.title: Unable to access the resource domain name
docs.text:
• The resource domain name is only valid in the intranet. Confirm the access scope first.

  • The resource domain name is resolved locally by the router. Please make sure that DNS encryption is not enabled on the device side and the DNS server is not pointed to an encrypted address such as 1.1.1.1.

docs.title: The device is not in the resource list
docs.text:
• Make sure that the device and the router are in the same network. It may take up to 2 minutes to discover the device when the device is connected to the network for the first time.

  • If there are multiple layers of NAT between the accessed device and the router, it needs to be added manually. This feature will be supported in version 0.6.0.

docs.title: The original IP address of the device is inaccessible
docs.text: • To avoid IP changes and subnet conflicts on the device, only accessible IPs assigned by astrowarp are supported for access.

docs.title: Unable to access the Internet
docs.text:
• If the exit node is in use, please confirm whether the exit node can access the Internet normally.

  • Try to restart (stop and then start) the astrowarp network.

  • Try to disable the astrowarp service on the router.

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.

docs.title: Create a basic network
docs.text:
For first-time users, we recommend setting up your AstroWarp network based on your specific needs. Here are some network setup options to choose from, depending on your scenario:

Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Remote Access

If you need to access your devices remotely, follow this guide.

Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Keep Your Home IP

This option is for users who want to maintain their home IP address while away.

Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Remote Networking

Ideal for users who need to set up a network between different locations.

Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Aggregation VPN

For those looking to combine multiple connections to increase speed and reliability.

After completing the creation of the basic network, we can continue reading to complete more complex operations.

docs.title: Add router nodes
docs.text: You can add more router nodes to the basic network to enrich your application.

docs.title: Node renaming
docs.text: To make the network clearer, we can set our favorite names for the nodes.

docs.title: Delete router nodes
docs.text: If the router node is no longer needed, we can delete it.

docs.title: Disable astrowarp services
docs.text: If you need to disable the astrowarp service on your router, you can turn off the virtual network connection in your router's details settings.

docs.title: Access permission settings
docs.text: Node access and resource access constitute the permission control mechanism of astrowarp, and the device is only allowed to access if both permissions are set correctly.

docs.title: Node access permissions
docs.text:
Draw a line on the topology map to establish a network connection between two nodes.

By clicking on the connection, we can set the access permissions between nodes through the permission switch on the right.

Notice: when you try to connect a router to a cloud node, it means that the current router uses the cloud node as the aggregate VPN exit. Currently, only EXCLUSIVE server support the aggregate VPN function.

docs.title: Resource access permissions
docs.text:
You can add or delete resources through the details interface of the node.

Or you can quickly add resources through the + sign on the right of the node.

docs.title: Accessible address (Virtual IP)
docs.text:
Once a resource is added, a virtual IP will be automatically assigned for access, virtual IP can effectively avoid subnet conflicts and IP changes between routers.

The virtual IP is not actually assigned to your device, but is done through NAT rules like the one below.

iptables -t nat -I POSTROUTING -d 10.0.2.3/32 -j DNAT --to-destination 192.168.99.171

The upper limit of virtual IP allocation is 254. If this number is exceeded, you need to delete some unused or infrequently used resources.

docs.title: Domain Name
docs.text:
You can set a domain name for local access for any resource. The domain name suffix is always atwp.net. The fixed suffix is for easier certificate issuance.

This domain name is resolved locally by the router, so please do not set DNS encryption on your access end or point the DNS service to other addresses.

docs.title: Exit Node Settings
docs.text:
Router nodes can be used as Internet exits.

Exit nodes are not used for any router nodes by default, so we need to set whether other routers use this exit.

docs.title: Switch Cloud Node Location
docs.text: In a few cases, the recommended server may be subject to some restrictions. If necessary, you can switch to a different server location.

How to Implement Remote Desktop on a Computer

How to Stream Games Using Remote Desktop

docs.title: How to Stream Games Using Remote Desktop
docs.text: Game streaming allows you to play high-performance games on any device remotely, whether you’re on a weaker PC, a laptop, or even a mobile device. This guide will help you set up remote desktop streaming for games using Windows Remote Desktop.

docs.title: Ensure Your Host PCIs Ready for Remote Desktop
docs.text:
• Check Windows Version: Ensure you are using Windows 10/11 Professional, Enterprise, or Education editions. Windows Home does not support Remote Desktop by default.
  • Enable Remote Desktop:
    1. Right-click on “This PC” or “My Computer” and select Properties.
    2. Click Remote Settings on the left.
    3. Under the Remote Desktop section, select “Allow remote connections to this computer.”
    4. Uncheck the box that says “Allow connections only from computers running Remote Desktop with Network Level Authentication” for easier connections.

docs.title: Set Up Your Firewall
docs.text:
• Allow Remote Desktop in Firewall:
    1. Go to Control Panel > System and Security > Windows Firewall.
    2. Click Allow an app or feature through Windows Firewall.
    3. Ensure “Remote Desktop” is checked in both private and public networks.

docs.title: Prepare Your Network
docs.text:
• Network Requirements:
    1. Make sure your Host PC is connected via AstroWarp for better connection stability.
    2. Distrebute your Host PC and make sure your Client PC can access it.
    3. Ensure the network is fast enough for gaming (recommended: 20Mbps or higher for streaming).

docs.title: Install and Configure a Game Streaming Client
docs.text:
Although Windows Remote Desktop is effective for work tasks, you might prefer a dedicated game streaming app for better performance. Here are two great options:

  • Steam Remote Play:

    1. Open Steam on your main computer.
    2. Enable Remote Play in Steam settings.
    3. Log into Steam from a secondary device (laptop, mobile, etc.) and start streaming games from your main PC.

  • NVIDIA GeForce Experience (for NVIDIA GPU users):

    1. Install NVIDIA GeForce Experience on your Gaming Host PC.
    2. Enable GameStream in the settings.
    3. Download the Moonlight app on your remote device and input accessable address(IP) to stream games from your Client PC.

docs.title: Connect and Start Streaming
docs.text:
• Open Remote Desktop on the Remote Device:
    1. On another device (Windows, macOS, or mobile), open the Remote Desktop Connection app.
    2. Enter the IP address which distrebute by AstroWarp.
    3. Input your credentials (username and password).
  • Adjust Streaming Quality:
    1. For smooth gameplay, lower the streaming quality if the connection is unstable. Most streaming apps (e.g., Steam, Moonlight) let you adjust resolution and frame rates.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Remote desktop game streaming allows you to access your powerful gaming PC from anywhere, turning any device into a gaming platform. By following this guide and using apps like Steam Remote Play or Moonlight, you can enjoy a seamless gaming experience, even on weaker devices.

Happy gaming!

Feel free to modify this tutorial based on your preferred tools or additional steps. Would you like me to help with specific images for this guide?

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.

docs.title: How to Implement Remote Desktop on a PC
docs.text: With AstroWarp, you can establish secure remote desktop connections to your PCs without the need for public IP addresses.

docs.title: Enable Remote Desktop
docs.text: Please follow the guide here to enable remote desktop on your PC: Enable Remote Desktop on Windows.

docs.title: Find the Username
docs.text:
Fellow the guide below to find the username for remote connection:

  1. Press the Windows key + I to open the Settings app.
  2. Click on "Accounts".
  3. In the left sidebar, click on "Your info".

  4. Under your profile picture and name, you will see the username associated with the Windows account.

docs.title: Configure the PC as accessible resource in the Network
docs.text:
The PC that needs to be remotely accessed is connected under the MT3000-Host. Click MT3000-Host, then click the + sign to add the PC as an accessible resource.

In the diagram, GLinet-SDWAN is shown as a computer already added as an accessible resource. Its virtual IP is 10.0.3.1.

docs.title: Connect to Remote Desktop
docs.text:
1. On another computer, open the "Remote Desktop Connection" program.

  2. Enter the computer name or IP address you recorded earlier and click "Connect".

  3. Enter the credentials. The username can find at previous step, click OK, then you will be able to access the remote desktop.

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.

docs.title: Bind router to GL account
docs.text:
• Follow the instructions below to log in to your GL.iNet account and bind your device.

Step 1: Access your router’s management interface and click on the cloud icon at the top of the page to enable it.

Step 2: Log in to your GL account or register for a new one

Note: Every router in the network must be signed in to the GL.iNet account.

docs.title: Connect device to the router
docs.text:
• If you are configuring for the first time, we recommend that you connect the device to the LAN port or WIFI of the router, which is applicable to all scenarios.
  • In many cases, our device is already in the existing network. At this time, we just need to add the router to the existing network. (Notice: Only applies to the case where the device is only used as the accessed end or the router is used as the exit node)

docs.title: Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Aggregation VPN
docs.text: This document will guide you in creating an Aggregated VPN link for internet access. By using an Aggregated VPN, users can enjoy a better online experience in certain scenarios.

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text: Before starting the configuration, please complete the preparations.

docs.title: Creating the Network
docs.text:
Step 1: Set a Network Name: Choose a name for your network, such as "mynet."

Step 2: Select the Connection Aggregation Scenario.

Step 3: Choose the Location and Traffic Plan.

Step 4: Select Routers for Aggregated VPN.

Step 5:After completing the payment, the following topology connection will be generated.

You can check if our public IP address matches the public IP address of the aggregation node via ipaddress.my.

Step 6: Once confirmed the IP address, you can test different application scenarios. For example, you can try disconnecting the router's tethering network connection during a video conference to observe if the call is interrupted due to network issues.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Q: Why is there no significant increase in speed with connection aggregation?

A: First, check if your speed has already reached the physical limit. For Spitz AX (GL-X3000)/Puli AX (GL-XE3000) devices, the aggregated physical limit is around 500 Mbps. The speed aggregation feature does not apply to scenarios with significant differences in link quality, such as bandwidth and latency. We do not recommend using Ethernet and cellular networks for aggregated connections.

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.

docs.title: Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Keep Your Home IP
docs.text: This document outlines how to use your home network as an internet exit while traveling. By accessing the internet through your home network, you can ensure security and privacy while bypassing some traditional VPN limitations. For example, many services like Netflix restrict the use of VPNs in various situations. However, if you access the internet through your home network, you will not encounter these restrictions.

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text: Before starting the configuration, please complete the preparations.

docs.title: Creating the Network
docs.text:
Step 1: Set a Network Name: Choose a name for your network, such as "mynet."

Step 2: Select the Site to Site Scenario.

Step 3: Choose Routers and Associated Server Locations

Step 4: If you choose a non-free service, you will enter the payment step. Complete the payment according to the guide, and the following topology will appear.

Step 5: Configure the Home node as the exit node, and set the Travel node to use this exit.

Once set, a small area icon will appear on the side of the connection near Home.

Step 6: Open a browser on the Travel side and check if our public IP address matches that of the home network via ipaddress.my.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Q: After setting the Travel node to use the internet exit, why is there an issue refreshing service websites?

A: After setting the exit node, the network may briefly disconnect, causing devices to be unable to access service websites and the internet. Please wait a moment (no more than 1 minute) for the connection to restore.

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.

docs.title: Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Remote Access
docs.text: This document outlines the steps to create a remote access scenario, allowing you to access your office computer from home.

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text: Before starting the configuration, please complete the preparations.

docs.title: Creating the Network
docs.text:
Step 1: Set a Network Name: Choose a name for your network, such as "mynet."

Step 2: Select the Site to Site Scenario.

Step 3: Choose Routers and Associated Server Locations

Step 4: If you choose a non-free service, you will enter the payment step. Complete the payment according to the guide, and the following topology will appear.

Step 5: To enhance security, we want to ensure that only the home computer can access the office computer without allowing reverse access. Click on the connection line between the two routers and disable the Office->Home access permission in the options on the right sidebar.

Step 6: Click the plus sign next to Office, select your office computer, and confirm. This indicates that your office computer is allowed to be accessed from the Home side.

Once access is granted, a virtual IP will be automatically assigned. You can view this by clicking on the corresponding router in the topology diagram.

Step 7: Using this virtual IP address, you can perform a series of remote operations on your office computer from the home computer, such as using Windows Remote Desktop Connection.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Q: What should I do if I cannot access Remote Desktop after following the setup steps? A: First, ensure you are using the virtual IP for access and that the username and password are correct. If the issue persists, check the firewall settings regarding permissions for the Remote Desktop application.

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.

docs.title: Setting Up AstroWarp with GL.iNet Routers: Remote Networking
docs.text: This document outlines the steps to create a remote network that connects resources from two offices, enabling mutual access.

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text: Before starting the configuration, please complete the preparations.

docs.title: Creating the Network
docs.text:
Step 1: Set a Network Name: Choose a name for your network, such as "mynet."

Step 2: Select the Site to Site Scenario.

Step 3: Choose Routers and Associated Server Locations

Step 4: If you choose a non-free service, you will enter the payment step. Complete the payment according to the guide, and the following topology will appear.

Step 5: Click on the connection line between the two routers to ensure that bidirectional access permissions are enabled.

Step 6: Click the plus sign next to Office1 and Office 2, select the devices you wish to access mutually, and confirm.

Once access is granted, a virtual IP will be automatically assigned. You can view this by clicking on the corresponding router in the topology diagram.

Note: Access between devices will occur via the virtual IP. You can perform a simple test using the ping command.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Q: What should I do if I cannot ping after following the setup steps?

A: First, ensure you are using the virtual IP for access and that the username and password are correct. If the issue persists, please check the firewall settings on the device being accessed.

Still have questions? Visit our Community Forum.
